channel.title: Raleigh NC Parks and Recreation News
channel.description: Latest news from Raleigh Parks and Recreation

item.title: Living Legends: C.A.R.V.E. into Black Raleigh (Dec 22, 2025)
item.description:
Panel Discussion: “Living Legends of Raleigh”



An unforgettable evening as we honor the living legends of Raleigh, North Carolina—visionaries, trailblazers, and community champions whose work has shaped the cultural, social, and economic landscape of the Black community. This powerful panel discussion will spotlight the individuals who have not only witnessed history but made history.

This celebration is a moment to give them their flowers, celebrate their resilience, and acknowledge the impact of their decades of service. Through conversation, storytelling, and shared wisdom, these icons will reflect on their journeys, the challenges they've overcome, and the legacy they continue to build.



Discussion Themes



Special Host - Les Long
Comedian • Entertainer • Radio Personality
Shared the stage with Charlie Wilson, Patti LaBelle, Mary J. Blige, Frankie Beverly & Maze, Steve Harvey & more.
Tune in every Sunday, 5- 7 p.m. on Choice FM 92.1 for Southern Soul Sundays with Les Long.



Location: John P. "Top" Green African American Cultural Center
Date: Sunday, Feb. 8
Time: 3 - 5 p.m.
Ages: All
Cost: Free
No Registration is Required

item.title: Savvy Sisters Golden Years Club Activities (Jan 7, 2026)
item.description:
Established in 2024, Savvy Sisters is a social club that encourages women aged 50+ to thrive through friendships, gatherings, off-site day trips, involvement in local charity support, speakers, arts and crafts, and more! Join us and see how you can be involved in our vibrant community and help to shape our future together!



Get into the Savvy Spirit with us! Come share in our story and be part of our 2026 in the making! It's going to be a memorable day of connection, laughter and community spirit, with a fantastic ice breaker that will have you mingling and laughing with fellow attendees; there will be games, gifts, raffles, bingo sessions, delicious treats, and shots of our "savvy sisters' good times together."



The State of North Carolina Department of Agriculture presentation by our president, Alice Christiansen. She will share the seasonal benefits and perks for our senior community offered by the Department. There will be fun quizzes, agricultural gifts, snacks, and prizes. Please contact Alice for more information at 919-434-6318.



Location: Five Points Center for Active Adults
Date: Wednesday, Jan. 14
Time: 11 a.m.- 12:30 p.m
Ages: 50 and up
Cost: Free
Register at RecLink

item.title: Get Ready for the Snowball Showdown! (Jan 7, 2026)
item.description:
This game will be full of laughs, speedy runs, and amazing teamwork as everyone jumps in to play this safe and exciting snowy adventure. But the fun doesn’t stop there! After the showdown, everyone gets to warm up with yummy snacks, including ooey-gooey, delicious s’mores for the sweetest ending ever!  Let the snowball fun begin!

Location: Powell Drive Park
Date: Friday, Feb. 20
Time: 5:45 - 6:45 p.m. (ages 6 - 7), 7:15 - 8:15 p.m. (ages 8 -9)
Ages: 6 - 9 
Cost: $10
Register on RecLink

item.title: Join the ZigZaggers at Powell Drive Park to get Active! (Jan 7, 2026)
item.description:
Location: Powell Drive Park
Date: Wednesdays
Time: 6 - 7 p.m. (Beginner level),  7 - 9 p.m. (Advanced Level)
Cost: $5 per month (Free in January and February)
Ages: 13 and up
Register on RecLink

item.title: Build Confidence Outdoors with Survival Skills Programs (Jan 7, 2026)
item.description:
From navigating the wilderness without technology to mastering practical knot-tying skills, these programs offer engaging experiences for all ages.



Learning knots has never been so fun! Kids will explore how knots are used in outdoor adventures, creative problem-solving, and everyday life. Participants will learn to tie several useful and impressive knots, practice their new skills, and finish the program by creating a paracord bracelet to wear home with pride. Adults must accompany children; accompanying adults attend free and do not need to register.

Location: Thomas G. Crowder Woodland Center
Dates and Times: Saturday, Jan. 17 (9 - 11 a.m.) and Sunday, March 8 (1 - 3 p.m.)
Ages: 7 - 12
Cost Free
Register on RecLink



Ready to unplug and try something new? Orienteering 101 offers adults the chance to step off the beaten path and into the woods of Lake Johnson Park with nothing but a map and a compass. This beginner-friendly course introduces the basics of navigation—reading a compass, taking bearings, and understanding topographic maps—so you can feel confident exploring without relying on your phone or GPS. No experience is needed, just a sense of curiosity and adventure. Advanced registration is required.

Location: Thomas G. Crowder Woodland Center
Date: Sunday, Feb. 8 and March 8 
Time: 1 - 4 p.m.
Ages: 16 and up
Cost: $12
Register on RecLink



These engaging programs are a great way to build skills, boost confidence, and create memorable outdoor experiences—whether you’re navigating the woods or tying your very first knot.



To register, visit RecLink.RaleighNC.gov or register in person at any community center.

item.title: Ready to Ride this Spring! (Jan 7, 2026)
item.description:
Hit the trails with Mountain Bike Basics in the morning and stay for Trailside Maintenance in the afternoon.



Location: Forest Ridge Park
Dates: Saturday, March 7 and April 18
Time: 9 - 11 a.m. (Mountain Bike Basics) /  1 - 3 p.m. (Trailside Maintenance)
Cost: Varies ($12 - $41)
Ages: 14 and older
Register on RecLink

item.title: Winter Tree Identification (Jan 7, 2026)
item.description:
In this program, you will learn to identify local trees based on bark, limb, buds, and branching patterns as well as leaves, seed,s and habitat. Participants will receive field guides for local trees to keep and take home. This is an outdoor event, and you should dress for the weather conditions. 

Participants are eligible to receive three hours of Criteria II (outdoor) or Criteria III credit toward N.C. Environmental Educator Certification. Sign up today and answer the question, 'What kind of tree is that?'

Location: Forest Ridge Park
Date: Sunday, Feb. 1
Time: 1 - 4 p.m.
Ages: 18 and up
Cost: $10
Register on RecLink

item.title: Sprouts Soccer, Preschool Program (Jan 7, 2026)
item.description:
Designed for ages 3–4, our program helps children build basic soccer skills, coordination, and confidence, all while having a great time. 

Each session meets once a week for a month, giving children a consistent routine to learn and grow. Come be a part of the fun! Participants should bring water and wear sneakers. Registration is required.

Location: Peach Road Park
Date: Wednesdays from April 1 - April 22 & May 6 - May 27
Time: 3:30 - 4:15 p.m.
Ages: 3 - 4
Cost: $41 Resident / $56 Non-Resident 
Register on RecLink

item.title: Share Your Ideas for Biltmore Hills Park (Jan 7, 2026)
item.description:
News Published 1/7/2026 Updated 1/7/2026



Community members are encouraged to participate either in person or online. Public input will help inform design options and shape the long-term vision for the expansion and enhancement of Biltmore Hills Park.

An Initial Input Public Meeting will be held on Thursday, Jan. 29, from 4 to 6 p.m. at the Biltmore Hills Community Center. This family-friendly public workshop will give participants the opportunity to learn about the project, explore early design ideas, and share feedback on what improvements are most important to them.

For those unable to attend in person, an online survey will be available from Jan. 26 through Feb. 16, providing another way to share input and participate in the planning process.

Accommodation and translation services are available upon request. Please email BiltmoreHillsUpdate@publicinput.com for assistance.



More information about the project, engagement opportunities, and online participation is available on the project engagement portal.



Location: Biltmore Hills Community Center
Date: Thursday, Jan. 29
Time: 4 - 6 p.m.
Ages: All
No Registration is Required



January 29, 2026 4:00PM



BiltmoreHillsUpdate@PublicInput.com



Biltmore Hills Park



This feedback widget is not intended for customer service issues.



This feedback is reviewed monthly to help us improve our site. For immediate customer service please refer to our staff directory.

item.title: Mental Health Check In (Jan 6, 2026)
item.description:
Globally, food is recognized as medicine, culture, and a cornerstone of community. This check-in invites us to begin approaching it in the same way, examining how our relationship with food shapes our well-being across multiple dimensions.



This experience reflects a grassroots approach to wellness—neighbors, professionals, and organizers working side by side to ensure our community has access to holistic, non-clinical support. Food and drinks will be available for purchase.

Hosted by Let’s Get Social Raleigh Foundation INC and John P. Top Green African American Cultural Center

Location: John P. "Top" Greene African American Cultural Center
Date: Monday, Feb. 2
Time: 6:30 - 9:30 p.m.
Ages: All
Cost: Free
No Registration Required

item.title: Poetry Jam & Creative Writing Throwdown (Dec 30, 2025)
item.description:
Join fellow writers and orators in an informal and welcoming space where we are free to craft, read, and spit poetry, prose, and spoken word. Whether you're working on a masterpiece or just jotting down thoughts, let's share inspiration and creativity as we unleash the powerful beauty of words. Bring your writing, your voice, and your open ear!



Location: Five Points Center for Active Adults
Date: The third Friday of every month
Time: 3 - 5 p.m.
Ages: 18 and older
Cost: Free
Register on RecLink

item.title: Introduction to Whitewater Kayaking (Dec 30, 2025)
item.description:
Our certified instructors will guide you through the basics, including how to launch your kayak, proper posture, paddle strokes, and self-rescue. Whether you are brand new to kayaking or looking to sharpen your skills, this pool-based class has you covered. All equipment is provided.

Please wear a bathing suit or other clothing that can get wet. Bring a towel, change of clothing, water bottle, and any necessary snacks. Goggles and nose clip are recommended but not required.

Location: Optimist Pool
Date: Saturday, Jan. 24
Time:  Noon - 4 p.m.
Ages: 14 and older 
Cost: $65 Residents / $80 Non-Residents
Register on RecLink

item.title: LGBTQIA+ Film Series (Dec 30, 2025)
item.description:
Join us for our monthly program on the first and fourth Tuesday of the month. We will be showcasing films with diverse themes around sexuality and gender. This program is co-hosted with the Carolina Aging Alliance.

Seating is limited, so please register in person or online. To register, visit reclink.raleighnc.gov and search keyword "LGBTQIA" or in person at any community center.



January's first film is "Beyond Stonewall: Exploring LGBTQ+ History Through the Smithsonian Archives," a deep dive into the incredible objects from the National Museum of American History that showcases the rich history of the LGBTQIA+ community, from the turn of the 20th century, through the Stonewall Riots in 1969, and beyond. 



Date: Tuesday, Jan. 6
Time: 2 - 4:15 p.m.
Age: 18 and older
Cost: Free
Register on RecLink



January's second film is "Weekend." After a drunken house party with his straight mates, Russell heads out to a gay club. Just before closing time, he picks up Glen but what's expected to be short lived becomes something special. This program is co-hosted with the Carolina Aging Alliance. 



Date: Tuesday, Jan. 27
Time: 2 - 4:15 p.m.
Age: 18 and older
Cost: Free
Register on RecLink



February's first film is "Desert Hearts". While waiting for her divorce papers, a repressed professor of literature is unexpectedly seduced by a carefree, spirited young lesbian.



Date: Tuesday, Feb. 3
Time: 2 - 4:15 p.m.
Age: 18 and older
Cost: Free
Register on RecLink



February's second film is "Beautiful Thing." Jamie is a shy teenager, often bullied at school. His neighbor Ste has a rough time at home, being beaten by his father and brother. This issues bring them together and they find that what they feel for each other is more than friendship.



Date: Tuesday, Feb. 17
Time: 2 - 4:15 p.m.
Age: 18 and older
Cost: Free
Register on RecLink

item.title: Art Classes at Five Points Center for Active Adults (Jan 6, 2026)
item.description:
Calligraphy and Watercolor



News Published 1/6/2026 Updated 1/6/2026



Discover the magic of watercolor! The instructor will introduce paper, brushes and other supplies and demonstrate these techniques. Master artists' work will be viewed to display their use of elements and principles of art. Students will have the opportunity to adopt, adapt, and/or apply to their own work. Students will practice using elements of texture, value, line, space, shape, and form, including the color wheel. Principles of art will be identified and discussed, along with the importance of leaving white space. Students will learn to use these techniques to create their own original art, whether still life, landscape, or abstract. You must bring supplies to class. Supply list available online or at the Five Points front desk.



Dates: Tuesdays,  Jan. 13 - Feb. 17
Time:  10:30 a.m. - 12:30 p.m.
Ages: 18 and older
Cost: $32 Residents / $47 Non-residents
Register on RecLink



Five Points Center for Active Adults welcomes senior art enthusiasts at any stage! We have a lot of fun classes, and engaging and knowledgeable instructors. Come learn calligraphy! Linda Torrena will teach participants how to utilize different brush strokes to create beautiful lettering. This workshop is once a month on the first Wednesday of the month.



Dates: First Wednesday of every month, Jan. 14 -April 8
Time: 10:30 a.m. - 12:30 p.m.
Ages: 18 and older
Cost: $29 for four months
Register on RecLink



This class can only be taken if you have taken a previous watercolor class before. Review techniques, color theory and use in painting still-life or photos of flowers, animals, etc. Address composition elements & principles. Discuss brushes and supplies, along with how to create form. Oriental brush assignment may be included along with color puzzles, explanation, and examples. Students will learn to use these techniques to create their own original art, whether still life, landscape or abstract. You must bring supplies to class. Supply list available online or at the Five Points front desk.



Dates: Thursdays, Jan. 15 - Feb. 12
Time:  10:30 a.m. - 12:30 p.m.
Ages: 18 and older
Cost: $32 Residents / $47 Non-residents
Register on RecLink



Five Points Center for Active Adults

item.title: Cupid's Workshop (Dec 29, 2025)
item.description:
Kids will have the chance to make handmade cards, gifts, and keepsakes for someone special. Supplies will be provided.



Location: Brier Creek Community Center
Date: Tuesday, Feb. 3
Time: 5:30 - 7 p.m.
Ages: 5 - 10
Cost: $5
Register on RecLink

item.title: New Year, New Classes! (Dec 29, 2025)
item.description:
Whether you want to sweat, build strength, or slow things down, our updated lineup offers something for every body and every goal, alongside our popular weekly yoga class.



Take your workout beyond four walls with this high-energy indoor/outdoor class at Lake Johnson. After a quick warm-up indoors, you’ll head outside to rotate through high-intensity stations using resistance bands, bodyweight exercises, jump ropes, jogging, and more. HIIT (High-Intensity Interval Training) is one of the most effective ways to boost metabolism and burn calories—perfect for anyone looking to jumpstart their fitness routine. Registration in advance is required.

Location: Thomas G. Crowder Woodland Center
Dates & Times: Starting in Feb. on the first Wednesdays (6 - 7 p.m.) and third Sundays (9 - 10 a.m.)
Ages: 18 and up
Cost: $14/session
Register on RecLink



Build strength, sculpt lean muscle, and learn smart training techniques in this hypertrophy-focused class. Using resistance bands, suspension trainers, and bodyweight exercises, you’ll target all major muscle groups with an emphasis on proper form and effective movement. This empowering class is ideal for adults ready to feel stronger and more confident in their workouts. Registration in advance is required.

Location: Thomas G. Crowder Woodland Center
Dates & Times: Starting in Feb. on the second Wednesdays (6 - 7 p.m.) and fourth Sundays (9 - 10 a.m.) 
Ages: 18 and older
Cost: $14/session
Register on RecLink



Our beloved yoga class continues at the Thomas G. Crowder Woodland Center, offering a peaceful midweek reset surrounded by wooded views. This all-levels class blends gentle stretching, mindful breathing, balance work, and flowing sequences to reduce stress, improve strength, and support alignment. Modifications and props make it accessible for everyone—just come as you are and leave feeling refreshed. Advance registration preferred, drop-in registration welcomed.

Location: Thomas G. Crowder Woodland Center
Date: Tuesdays starting Jan. 6
Time: 6:30 - 7:30 p.m.
Ages: 18 and older
Cost: $61 Residents /  $76 Non-residents per 6-week session
Register on RecLink

item.title: Evening Yoga at Halifax Community Center (Dec 23, 2025)
item.description:
Join this all-levels yoga class where you can progress at your own pace in a supportive environment. This weekly class offers a well-rounded practice to support strength, mobility, and stress relief. 

Bring your mat and any props (blocks, straps, blanket) that support you. Expect a little movement, a little sweat, and a lot of good vibes!

Location: Halifax Community Center
Date: Thursdays starting Jan. 8
Time: 6 - 7 p.m.
Ages: 18 and older
Cost: $15 for drop-in / $55 for monthly
Register on RecLink

item.title: Free Friday at Mordecai Historic Park (Dec 23, 2025)
item.description:
Mordecai Historic Park will offer free tours throughout the day on this special Friday! Tours include the Mordecai House, Andrew Johnson’s birthplace, St. Mark’s Chapel, and the Allen Kitchen.



Tours begin every 30 minutes and are limited to 20 people per tour. Starting at the Visitor Center, the first tour will begin at 10:00 a.m. and the last tour starts at 3:00 p.m.

No registration is necessary. For more information, please call 919-996-4364.

Location: Mordecai Historic Park
Date: Friday, Jan. 23
Time: 10 a.m. - 4 p.m.
Ages: All
Cost: Free

item.title: Dr. M.T. Pope House Presents: Evelyn's Book Club (Jan 5, 2026)
item.description:
Evelyn, a college librarian born in 1908 and died in 1995, loved a variety of books from The Adventures of Tom Sawyer to Shakespeare and James Baldwin. The program brings community members together monthly at the museum to discuss books, focusing on works by Black writers or featuring Black subjects, including fiction and non-fiction. Discussions will use questions to facilitate conversation.



Registration opens Jan. 23.  An optional book bundle will be available to purchase at registration. Books can be picked up at the Dr. M.T. Pope House Museum.

item.title: Sign Up for Volleyball Skills Training at Biltmore Hills Community Center (Jan 2, 2026)
item.description:
We will also work on the importance of sportsmanship and how to behave in a team environment. The goal of this program is to prepare our athletes to compete at the highest level all while making it affordable and creating the best experience for our participants.

Location: Biltmore Hills
 Date: Mondays and Wednesdays
Time: 7:30 - 8:45 p.m.
Ages: 10 - 14
Cost: $225 Monthly Fee / $30 Drop In
Register on RecLink

item.title: Wilderness Navigation (Jan 2, 2026)
item.description:
Come join an experienced instructor as they teach the basics of using a map and a compass through more advanced skills, so you can stay found and get where you want to go while you are in the wilderness.

Please bring a water bottle and be prepared to spend time outside. Wear clothes that you will be comfortable hiking off-trail in. We will provide all necessary equipment.



Location: Forest Ridge Park
Dates: Tuesdays & Thursdays - Jan. 15, Feb. 12, March 10, April 16
Time: 5:30 - 7:30 p.m.
Ages: 14 and up
Cost: $25 Residents / $40 Non Residents
Register on RecLink

item.title: Call for Nominations: Fred Fletcher Outstanding Volunteer Awards (Jan 1, 2026)
item.description:
This annual event recognizes individuals and groups whose exceptional service and commitment have made a significant impact within the Raleigh Parks Department and the communities that we serve.



We invite community members, organizations, and colleagues to participate in this important recognition process. By submitting a nomination, you help ensure that the invaluable contributions of our volunteers are acknowledged and celebrated.



For More information about the award categories and the nomination process, please visit our website.

item.title: Girls' Tea & Triumph: Sip, Play, and Shine for a Cause (Dec 22, 2025)
item.description:
Kick off the event with a charming tea time, featuring a variety of delicious teas and treats to enjoy while mingling with new friends. Get ready to socialize and engage in lively games that promote laughter and connection across generations. As we wrap up our delightful afternoon, gather around for a game of bingo, where everyone has a chance to win fabulous prizes!




In the spirit of community, we’re also collecting clean packs of women ’s-sized underwear as donations for our local women's center. So, bring your generous hearts along with your playful spirits! Come dressed in your best tea party attire! Please note this is not a floating event; tea will be held from 5 to 5:20 p.m., and activities will follow.

Location: Kiwanis Park
Date: Friday, Feb. 20
Time: 5 - 6:30 p.m.
Ages: 3 and older (accompanied by an Adult)
Cost: Free
Register on RecLink

item.title: Seasonal Stretch: Yoga at Fred Fletcher (Dec 22, 2025)
item.description:
In this alignment-focused series of 3 classes, you'll learn how to work from a stable base to feel more grounded both physically and mentally, while also improving range of motion, posture, and balance. Props and modifications are available to meet you where you are. No yoga experience necessary.



Classes will be inside The Historic Borden Building unless weather permits the use of the Amphitheater.

Location: Fred Fletcher Park - Historic Borden Building
Dates: Tuesdays on Jan. 13, Feb. 17, March 24
Time: 11 a.m. - noon 
Ages: 18 and older
Cost: $30 (3-session package)
Register on RecLink

item.title: Join the Raleigh Parks Team! (Dec 22, 2025)
item.description: We're hiring for various part-time roles in parks, community centers, pools, and programs. Explore open positions and apply now to be part of something exceptional!

item.title: The January - April 2026 Leisure Ledger is Available! (Dec 19, 2025)
item.description:
You can grab a Leisure Ledger at park offices throughout Raleigh or browse online.



Check out all our programs and register at reclink/raleighnc.gov.

item.title: Join Us for Family and Youth Programs (Dec 19, 2025)
item.description:
Hill Street Neighborhood Center



News Published 12/19/2025 Updated 12/19/2025



Zumbini combines music, movement, and interactive activities that help children develop coordination, social skills, and self-expression, all while having a blast! Parents will love watching their kids build confidence and friendships in a safe, supportive environment.



Dates: Mondays, Jan. 5 - Feb. 2
Time: 4:45 - 5:30 p.m. (Ages: 2-3), 5:30 - 6:15 p.m. (Ages: 4-5)
Ages: 2-3 and 4-5
Cost: $40
Register on RecLink



Your little dancer will have tons of fun learning the basics of ballet and tap. The class will help them develop balance, coordination, and self-confidence. They will learn basic techniques, body positions, and steps. Everything they learn will come together in an end-of-course performance for the parents to enjoy.



Dates: Tuesdays, Jan. 6 - 27
Times: 4:45 - 5:15 p.m. 
Ages: 2 - 3
Cost: $30
Register on RecLink



Your little dancer will have tons of fun learning the basics of ballet and tap. The class will help develop balance, coordination, and self-confidence. Students will learn basic technique, body position, and steps.



Dates: Tuesdays, Jan. 6 - 27
Times: 5:15 - 6:15 p.m.
Ages: 4 - 5
Cost: $40
Register on RecLink



Your dancer will have tons of fun learning the basics of ballet, tap, and jazz. This class will help them develop balance, coordination, and self-confidence. All while learning basic technique, body positions and steps in each style of dance. Everything they learn will come together for an end-of-session performance for the parents to enjoy.



Date: Thursdays, Jan. 8 - 29
Time: 5:30 - 6:30 p.m.
Ages: 6 - 12 
Cost: $40
Register on RecLink



This fun yoga series combines age-appropriate poses with imaginative yoga adventures, delightful books and music while offering a special time for parents and caregivers to connect with their child. Grown ups, get your silly hats on! We will hiss in cobra pose, bark in downward dog, and flutter our wings in butterfly all while building strength, coordination, and balance! Your little yogi will love this class with you and everyone will leave more centered and ready to face the weekend. Grown-ups and children should both wear clothes for movement. Please bring a yoga mat. Register child only.



Date: Saturdays, Jan. 10-31
Time: 11:15 a.m. - Noon
Ages: 3 - 5
Cost: $40
Register on RecLink



Hill Street Park
2307 Hill Street
Raleigh, NC 27604



919-996-5300



Hill Street Park

item.title: Greenway After Dark Series (Dec 19, 2025)
item.description:
This drop-in program is set up to allow you to get outside, enjoy the greenway, and meet your fitness goals this winter.  We will meet at designated locations, and you will be able to move down the greenway and back as you choose.  

Each week, we will have a different section of the greenway available to accommodate up to a 3-mile (5Km) run or walk.  Strollers and pets are welcome. Parks staff will be available to provide general direction and support during the program timeframe. 

Pre-registration helps us prepare, but is not required.  Get up-to-date location and weather alerts here.



Time: 5 - 8 p.m.
Ages: 16 and older
Cost: Free
Register on RecLink

item.title: Share Your Feedback on the Neuse River Park Schematic Design (Dec 18, 2025)
item.description:
The schematic design phase builds on the community-supported master plan and begins to show how features such as trails, play areas, open spaces, and natural areas will take shape on the site. 

Community feedback will help guide the next steps in refining the design and preparing for future construction.

The online survey is available through Monday, Dec. 29.



Take the survey and learn more .

item.title: High School Art Submissions Needed for Exhibition! (Dec 18, 2025)
item.description:
Our High School Student Council is turning the museum into the ultimate creative playground! Think art competitions, jam sessions, and a student-run art market buzzing with energy.



Accepting visual arts and literary submissions for our theme:
Raleigh Memory - Progress, Nostalgia, People.



Accepting art market vendor submissions from all high school-age students.



Date: Saturday, Feb. 21
Time: 10 a.m. - 2 p.m.
Ages: High School Age 
Cost: Free

item.title: Plant Swap! (Dec 18, 2025)
item.description:
Bring your favorite house and garden plants or homegrown vegetables to trade with fellow plant enthusiasts. We ask that you bring only healthy, pest-free plants to ensure everyone’s enjoyment. This event is free and open to the public!



Location: City of Raleigh Museum
Date: Saturday, Jan. 17
Time: 11 a.m. - 1 p.m.
Ages: All
Cost: Free

item.title: Pals & Gals Vintage Valentines Party (Dec 18, 2025)
item.description:
We will provide all of the crafting supplies and the ambiance. This is a wonderful activity for couples, friends, and folks looking to build new community, all for a good cause. 100% of profits from this event go to support free educational programs at the museum.



Location: City of Raleigh Museum
Date: Friday, Feb. 13
Time: 7 - 9 p.m.
Age: 21 and up
Cost: $35
Register Today

item.title: Winnie The Pooh Day! (Dec 17, 2025)
item.description:
We’ll read our favorite stories, re-enact some favorite scenes, play games, and make crafts to take home!



Preregistration is required for each participant. Parents/Guardians should plan to stay for the entire program.



Location: Laurel Hills Community Center
Date: Friday, Jan. 16
Time: 10:30 - 11:30 p.m.
Ages: 3 - 5
Cost: $8
Register on RecLink

item.title: Celebrate Black History Month at Chavis Park (Dec 17, 2025)
item.description:
This celebration offers a variety of activities aimed at educating, inspiring, and bringing people together. There will be food trucks, lessons for littles, Black-Owned Business Vendors, bounce houses, arts and crafts, and much more! We hope to see you there.



Location: John Chavis Community Center
Date: Saturday, Feb. 7
Time: 11 a.m. - 2 p.m.
Ages: All 
Cost: Free
No registration is required

item.title: Teen Trek Out! (Dec 17, 2025)
item.description:
The Teen Trek Out experience is one like no other.  Enjoy a day packed with adventure, laughs, and a good time. Join us as we venture across Raleigh for two fieldtrips and lunch because days off should never be boring. See you there!



Location: Peach Road Park
Date: Monday, Jan. 26
Time: 8 a.m. - 5:30 p.m.
Ages: 12 - 17
Cost: $60 Residents / $75 Non-residents
Register on RecLink

item.title: Beat the Winter Splash Blues! (Dec 17, 2025)
item.description:
Dive into the warmth and excitement at Buffaloe Road Aquatic Center! From floating along our lazy river to racing down the water slide or shooting hoops at the basketball goal, there’s something for everyone to enjoy—no winter coats required! 



Monday - Saturday: 10 a.m. - 7 p.m.
Sunday: 1 - 5 p.m.



Closed: Wednesday, Dec. 24 - Friday, Dec. 26
Open: Wednesday, Dec. 31 from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.
Closed: Thursday, Jan. 1



Make Buffaloe Road Aquatic Center your go-to spot this winter break for family fun, laughter, and a splash of summer—right in the middle of winter!

item.title: John Chavis Memorial Park Presents King Day (Dec 17, 2025)
item.description:
This special event will honor Dr. King’s legacy through meaningful service opportunities, engaging children’s activities, and community-centered experiences. 

Join us as we reflect, connect, and celebrate the impact of Dr. King’s life and work. This event is free and open to all ages.

Location: John Chavis Memorial Park
Date: Monday, Jan. 19
Time: Noon - 3 p.m.
Ages: All
Cost: Free
No registration is required

item.title: Take a Class at Pullen Arts Center (Dec 16, 2025)
item.description:
Check out some upcoming classes at Pullen Arts Center, and use the links below to register online!



For a full list of classes available, visit RecLink  or preview upcoming classes and programs in the Leisure Ledger.

item.title: Beginners Art and Craft (Dec 15, 2025)
item.description:
Through hands-on projects, participants explore various artistic techniques, learn new craft skills, and use art as a tool for communication, relaxation, and connection. The program encourages collaboration, celebrates diversity, and supports personal and social development through creative activities.



Pamela Douglas brings a lifelong passion for fashion, design, and creative expression to her role as a Teaching Artist with the Art & Craft program at Biltmore Hills. She will also share her talents with the John P. “Top” Greene African American Cultural Center, where she leads beginner classes every Tuesday from 1 - 3 p.m. starting January 20. In each setting, Pamela is dedicated to introducing participants to a wide range of art forms and creating a warm, collaborative atmosphere that encourages exploration and skill-building. She believes that making art together not only nurtures individual creativity but also strengthens community bonds and deepens our shared sense of humanity.

Location: John P. "Top" Greene African American Cultural Center
Date:  Tuesdays, starting January 20
Time: 1 - 3 p.m.
Ages: All
Cost: $15
Register on RecLink

item.title: Celebrate the Holidays with Raleigh Parks (Dec 15, 2025)
item.description:
Browse our upcoming events below or check out additional programs online via RecLink . 



Stay tuned for more Raleigh Parks Holiday events as they get added!

item.title: Seize the Night Trail Run is Back! (Dec 12, 2025)
item.description:
Bundle up, lace up, and bring a light to run the Shoreline Trail at Forest Ridge Park after hours! This is a social, no-drop, group trail run. Participants must use a headlamp or flashlight while on the trail. Seize the Night!



Location: Forest Ridge Park
Days: Wednesdays, Jan. 21 and Feb. 25
Time: 6 - 8 p.m.
Ages: 16 and up
Cost: $2
Register on RecLink

item.title: Lunch Box Lectures at the City of Raleigh Museum (Dec 11, 2025)
item.description:
Bring your lunch to the City of Raleigh Museum and listen to a captivating lecture every third Thursday of the month. 



This program is in partnership with the City of Raleigh Active Adults Program.



Time: noon - 12:45 p.m.
Ages: All
Cost: Free

item.title: Veterans and Coffee (Dec 10, 2025)
item.description:
We're proud to host Veterans & Coffee, a monthly community event dedicated to supporting and educating our local veterans. Each month, we’ll host a 1-hour workshop focused on important topics that matter to those who’ve served.



Our goal is to raise awareness and spread valuable knowledge to veterans and their families in our area. Come enjoy a cup of coffee, connect with fellow veterans, and gain helpful insights. Let’s honor our veterans by staying informed and connected. All are welcome!



Led by Elree T. Smith, Past Department Commander, Veterans of Foreign Wars, Department of North Carolina.

item.title: Level Up Your Babysitting Game (Dec 9, 2025)
item.description:
Through engaging activities, group discussions, and hands-on practice, participants will gain the confidence to provide competent care for children and infants.



Our certified instructors will guide students through the essentials of managing real-life babysitting scenarios, from handling common challenges to responding effectively in an emergency.

Location: Barwell Road Community Center
Date: Monday, Feb. 16
Time: 8 a.m. - 5:30 p.m.
Ages: 11 - 14
Cost: $50 Residents / $65 Non-Residents
Register on RecLink

item.title: Weather Bound Program Open December 9 (Dec 8, 2025)
item.description:
News Published 12/8/2025 Updated 12/8/2025



When school is unexpectedly closed due to weather, Raleigh Parks’ Weather Bound program is here to help! We provide a fun, safe place for kids to spend the day with games, crafts, and active play—led by caring Raleigh Parks staff. The program will run from 10:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Cost: $39.

Locations:
Abbotts Creek
Brier Creek
Jaycee
John Chavis Memorial Park



Register Here



We look forward to seeing your child for a fun and engaging Weather Bound day!



This feedback widget is not intended for customer service issues.



This feedback is reviewed monthly to help us improve our site. For immediate customer service please refer to our staff directory.

item.title: Drumming Showcase (Dec 8, 2025)
item.description:
Explore different drumming traditions, enjoy hands-on crafts, and pick up something from a local food truck.



This event is presented in partnership with the Japan America Society of North Carolina .



Location: Five Point Center for Active Adults
Date: Saturday, Jan. 24
Time: 11 a.m. - 2 p.m.
Ages: All
Cost: Free

item.title: January Preschool Programs (Dec 8, 2025)
item.description:
Join the young explorers club for a hike and seasonal lesson, learn all about the winter sun, or discover which animals work the night shift.



Location: Forest Ridge Park
Time: 10:30 a.m. - noon
Ages: 3 - 6
Browse and Register on RecLink

item.title: Winter Weather: Impacts to the City (Dec 8, 2025)
item.description:
The City's garbage, recycling, and yard waste collection may be delayed due to winter weather. Please leave carts at the curb until serviced. We will not issue warnings or fines during this period.



Check our Events feed to see if other specific events or meetings have been canceled or postponed. 



Need a warm place to stay the night? Need a meal for your family? Need shoes or a coat? 

View our list of resources.



Review locations serving as White Flag Shelters, and information about when other community partners will be open. 



White Flag Shelters

item.title: Moore Square Winterfaire (Dec 5, 2025)
item.description:
From Dec. 11-14, Moore Square will transform into a festive destination filled with local makers and artisans, delicious food trucks, a cozy beer garden, live performances, holiday crafts, games, and a visit from Santa himself.

Inspired by the charm of traditional Holiday markets, Moore Square Winterfaire brings a North Carolina twist to the experience — blending Southern hospitality, creative spirit, and community celebration in the heart of downtown Raleigh.

This event is free to attend and open to all ages. Visitors can stroll through twinkling lights, shop for handcrafted gifts, enjoy local flavors, and make new memories in one of Raleigh’s most beloved urban parks. Learn more about Winterfaire



Did you attend Winterfaire? Share your experience with us!

item.title: 2026 Emancipation Day Breakfast (Dec 3, 2025)
item.description:
Emancipation Day is a day of Rejoicing! On January 1st, 1863, President Abraham Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation, freeing enslaved African Americans in the South. This proclamation inspired many to run away and join the frontlines of the Union army. After fighting, many decided to commemorate this Proclamation; thus, Emancipation Day was born.



Usually celebrated on January 1st in North Carolina, Emancipation Day featured parades, dances, and speeches. After 1865, many African Americans navigated the complicated reality of balancing their new freedom within existing societal discrimination. Our lecturer will discuss this reality regarding firearms and gun ownership in the 1800s. Books can be purchased at the Event!



New nuance to old gun debates in the Tar Heel State

Spanning the 1720s through the end of the Civil War, this book explores how free and enslaved Black North Carolinians accessed, possessed, and used firearms—both legal and otherwise—and how the state and white people responded. North Carolinians, whether free or enslaved, Black or white, had different stakes on the issue, all of which impacted the reality of Black people’s gun use.



Antwain K. Hunter reveals that armed Black people used firearms for a wide range of purposes: They hunted to feed their families and communities, guarded property, protected crops, and defended maroon communities from outsiders. Further, they resisted the institution of slavery and used guns both against white people and within their own community. Competing views of Black people’s firearm use created social, political, and legal points of contention for different demographics within North Carolina and left the general assembly and white civilians struggling to harness Black people’s armed labor for white people’s benefit. A Precarious Balance challenges readers to rethink how they understand race and firearms in the American past.
